title: Ticket #2699: QSUB emulation for Condor
description:
Earlier this year I asked if there is a way to perform SGE-style
submissions of dependent jobs with Condor (i.e. qsub -hold_jid ...)

https://lists.cs.wisc.edu/archive/condor-users/2011-January/msg00161.shtml

The conclusion of this thread was that there is no built-in tool, but it
wouldn't be impossible to build something like this from the building
blocks that Condor provides. So I sat down and tried to come up with
something minimalistic that does the job for our specific use-case.  I
ended up with a shell script that behaves like qsub (to a certain
extent) and prepares submit files for condor_submit.  It supports single
jobs (scripts and command lines), array jobs ($SGE_TASK_ID,...) and
specification of job dependencies via -hold_jid (monitored via a simple
sentinel job running in the local universe).

I'm attaching the current version of the script to this email, in case
someone wants to use it as a source of inspiration. Any potential future
development can be followed here:

http://anonscm.debian.org/gitweb/?p=pkg-exppsy/condor.git;a=blob_plain;f=debian/condor_qsub;hb=HEAD

I'd be glad to get feedback and patches.

Michael
remarks:
2012-Sep-26 14:06:03 by tstclair:
So I'm cleaning out some lingering tickets..

What is the primary driver here?

  • ~ ease of command line equivs for those familiar with SGE?
  • It seems awfully close to condor_run.

2012-Sep-26 15:12:37 by mih:
This is not really intended to be used by humans (although it could be). Its purpose is to serve as an adaptor between Condor and software that has been written to interact with SGE.

condor_run imitates a (blocking) call to a (local) command. condor_qsub imitates a (non-blocking) call to a job-submission command (and to qsub in particular).

In any case, it does not support to complete qsub API and is therefore limited to a subset of all potentially interesting use cases. However, it is currently very useful for interfacing to two core tools for neuro-imaging research (Nipype and FSL). There respective Debian packages are configured to work out-of-the-box with Condor, by using condor_qsub as adaptor.

2012-Sep-26 15:25:22 by tstclair:
Seems contrib worthy, but I don't know if I would put it in mainline, because it's focus seems special purposed.

Was your goal just upstream integration?

2012-Sep-26 15:38:10 by mih:
I don't know whether the focus is too special -- it is definitely not focused on neuroimaging -- that is just were I happen to use it.

But I have no preference on where it should end up. Before I wrote it I found numerous requests for such tool, and several attempts that were outdated/broken/inaccessible. It seems like a waste not to have something like this somewhere close to Condor itself.

But again, if you use Condor with custom build binaries (like most people seem to do) it is not very useful. However, in our field the software situation is different. We have to deal with big ready-made toolkits that cannot talk to Condor natively. We can either use SGE (or some clone), or have to apply some glue...

2012-Oct-23 14:42:45 by nwp:
Is there anyone CHTC works with now that wants to use Condor and is currently using SGE for the purposes of being a guinea pig for this?
2013-Jan-22 10:54:51 by johnkn:
Bulk change of target version from v070903 to v070904 using ./ticket-target-mover.

2013-Mar-04 17:43:34 by samf:
There are several other groups that have made something similar.

qsub and more scripts Another qsub Maybe has a qsub

I'm looking at the features of each.

2013-Mar-05 10:58:27 by johnkn:
Bulk change of target version from v070904 to v070905 using ./ticket-target-mover.

2013-Mar-12 14:08:27 by samf:
I've uploaded Version 0.2 of condor_qsub to the main HTCondor source code tree. You can find it on the master branch in condor_scripts. If anybody wants to test it, I'd love to hear issues with it. I have a small test script for condor_qsub that I can either attach to the ticket or place somewhere in the HTCondor source code tree.

2013-Mar-12 15:42:59 by dweitzel:
Looking over the code, I see: 
sge_regex='^#SGE '

The SGE submit scripts I have used use #$ to specify SGE commands. Should #? be added as an addition method of specifying sge options?

2013-Mar-21 11:34:13 by samf:
I'm calling it "finished" for now. We can reopen the ticket later if/when more editing needs to be done.

2013-Apr-17 11:28:23 by tannenba:
How did this ticket make it to resolved w/o any documentation? I think we need a command reference page in the manual (that is also transformed into a man page) for this command at the least, that discusses:

  1. command line usage and options, just like any other man page
  2. what qsub functionality is supported and what is not,
  3. if we think it should work for most basic SGE submit files, or PBS submit files, or both
  4. some examples

I am moving this ticket from status resolved back to status docpending....

2013-Apr-17 14:34:41 by samf:
Sorry about that. I went to change the status earlier and I clicked on the wrong one. I'll work on the documentation.

2013-May-07 07:20:37 by bbockelm:
Hi samf,

A few things: 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest condor]$ ./src/condor_scripts/condor_qsub
./src/condor_scripts/condor_qsub: line 319: $1: unbound variable

Should probably print the help message, not a perl error. Then, 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest condor]$ ./src/condor_scripts/condor_qsub -h
^C

I'm not sure what that's supposed to do. According to the "-help" output, it: 

-h
  Implemented as listed.

Don't know what that means.

No man page yet? I assume that's just because it's on the TODO list. The "-help" output really could use some assistance too. I know it says to refer to the qsub manual - but that's fairly unsatisfying user experience.

2013-May-07 13:44:07 by samf:
I'm actively working on the manpage. There is just a lot of work put into it. I haven't pushed it yet to the master branch. There are some other tweaks as well.

As for printing the help message by default, yeah, that would be good. I'll work on that shortly.

As for the "-h" option, this is a valid option in PBS, Torque, and the POSIX standard. It means to submit a job on hold; I didn't write qsub to be like this, but I nevertheless need to try to emulate how qsub works. I do at least reference in condor_qsub where to find the manual pages online. And the original "help" page for condor_qsub was to list how condor_qsub worked differently than the specified version. Since I was told not to do that, I'm working on the manpage and replicating a lot of information, synthesizing across the different qsub implementations, and cross-referencing within the HTCondor manual. The man page should be in 7.9.6 (fingers crossed). Frantically working on it.

2013-May-24 16:22:53 by samf:
I've added a lot of documentation to condor_qsub and Karen has helped a lot tighten it up.
